name.value: BCT Command: Kandahar – Joint Warfare in Afghanistan

item.description:
BCT (Brigade Combat Team): Kandahar is an operational level wargame of operations in Afghanistan during the War on Terror. One player takes the role of a Coalition Force commander, the other the role of an Insurgent Force commander. Each player must accomplish objectives within a particular region, using a range of regular and irregular forces.

Player decisions reflect actual Task Force Group level command via a Military Staff System. Each turn, players allocate operational capabilities, represented by Joint Operations Cards. How well a player conducts his joint operations often determines the outcome of battles. But combat is not simply attrition of enemy forces. It also includes the effects of both military and political operations, as well as intelligence play. Consequently, players must think along several fronts of modern conflict.

A critical note: BCT Command: Kandahar uses many procedures similar to those currently utilized by U.S. and other Coalition forces. However, a number of abstractions were made to provide a playable game in a reasonable format.

Objective Cards are a quantification of political determination as well as the goals for which players are fighting. A player can use Objective Cards to guide their game strategy as well as to gain certain advantages. Much of the game is in determining the enemy Objective, and then taking appropriate counteraction. Often, your Objectives will conflict with your military operations, and it is up to you, the player, to determine the advantages or disadvantages of certain courses of action.

From publisher page:

"Enter the world of The Godfather Collector’s Edition of MONOPOLY, where you “keep your friends close, but your enemies closer.” Buy, sell and trade your way through the most memorable locations from The Godfather movie trilogy. Buy a stake in Moe Green’s Casino or take over the Corleone Lake Tahoe Estate as you work your way to the top in the “family business.” And as you wheel and deal around the board, from the Woltz Mansion to the legitimate Genco Import Company, remember to “make them an offer they can’t refuse.”

Rettet die Fische is a non-competitive dice-rolling game for very young children. The board shows a pond consisting of six water tiles. On these, eighteen fish tiles of various colors are laid out. Players then take turns rolling the die. If a fish symbol is rolled, a fish of that color is removed ("saved"). If a fire symbol turns up, however, there is a fire in the village and the firefighters need water from the pond - one water tile is removed. The players win if they can rescue all the fish, they lose if the pond goes dry.

Paquet voleur is a board game adapted from the television version. Strategy game, knowledge and bluff. Who will be the big winner? Combining general knowledge, strategy, luck and courage, this exciting game is for players with cunning and good bluffing who will try to get the pellets containing the largest amounts of money and gain access to the Final Round. Strategy, thinking and nerves of steel are the party!

The goal is to accumulate the largest amount of money by collecting the money contained in pellets. Each round you get a new pellet and you must decide to either keep it or try to steal another player's pellet. That player can try to block that theft by correctly answering a general knowledge question. At the end of each round a player is eliminated until someone reaches the final round in which he or she will try to make more money in that single round than any other player.

Siegecraft is a quick two-player, asymmetric, dice allocation game - available as a print-and-play game from July 2012.

Players take the role of either attacker or defender of a medieval castle. Over the course of five turns, players roll dice representing their available troops and decide whether to allocate them directly to the conflict on the walls or send them to man siege engines and defences - including boiling oil, battering rams and ballistae.

The game is simple to learn and quick to play but presents players with interesting and varied challenges.

Players can get the rules and board below, in Files. They will also need 35 D6s (20 for the attacker and 15 for the defender).

Two fleets fight for Midway, the japanese try to disembark on Midway and the US player avoiding it. The map is divided in squares for movement with Midway in the middle. The counters are plastic miniatures. Each unit has different movement and firepower. First move and combat the japanese player (using a table and the dice), but with only one unit each turn, then the US player do the same.
A player win the game if complete one of the three ways: invading the midway island, sinking the two transports or losing all units except the last one.

Fantail Handball is another board game of the Line Fantail dedicated to sports. It is a didactic and very entertaining board game where two teams develop Handball in a board game by using (2) smart charts each. Because it has a single disc on the board which is used as a ball, the Fantail Handball is a game very agile. In the smart carts are designed rules and tactics of Handball. Through the launch of a role given to 8 faces in smart charts are being obtained different game variations, which can lead to the movement of the ball among players in attack, cause the exclusion of a player, cause a foul, result in passive play or score a goal.
The symbols printed on the smart charts are in direct relation to the symbols printed on the game board.

This is sort of an odd entry which fits with this odd game. In part this entry is to document that Scarnie was not a predecessor of Scarney. John Scarne used his name in many games in many variations. It makes trying to reconstruct his contributions to board games even more frustrating. Having never seen the game itself, I'll attempt to describe it from the rules. Unfortunately there doesn't seem to be quite enough information to entirely reconstruct this game.

To make matters a bit more confusing in his book The odds against me Scarne has a 1929 picture of him playing a game named Scarney with Jimmy Braddock. The picture shows a game which fits this Scarnie game for which the rules are available (see weblinks). Being a good promoter Scarne didn't show him opposing the water boy at the boxing camp, but the champ himself!

Equipment

Scarnie is played on a board with four stations. Each station has the numbers 1 to 7 arranged in a semi-circle arranged in front of the player. There is common "pool" area in the center of the table.

There are 28 men which we will say are black discs. There is a number on one side of the disc, with each disc having one of the numbers between 1 and 28. 20 numbers are say red, and eight are say green. (Sorry but rules don't specify color/number association!!).

Play

The men are place numbers down in the pool area, and then each player fills his stations consecutively (thereby selecting seven pawns total for the station) and keeping the numbers hidden from the other players. The dealer calls "play" and the men are turned over to reveal the numbers.

The rules mention "Double", "Triple" , and "Draw" positions which I cannot explain. The available rules do describe other aspects of play. The gist is however that the pawns are eliminated from the board, and the last pawn left on the board scores points for that player.

Fantail Volleyball is another board game of the line Fantail dedicated to sports. It is a board game didactic and very entertaining, where two teams develop Volleyball in a board game by using (2) smart charts each. On the game board there is only a piece to be moved by each team in turn, which makes the game very agile. In the smart charts are designed rules and tactics of Volleyball. Smart charts begin with a decision, the player can choose float or power stroke. Then the dice 12-sided role, according to the number thrown, will derive on smart charts in different variants, which can result on hitting the ball by the forwards, or produce the opposing team simple, double or triple block, or the recovery or loss of the ball, or the obtaining or loss of the point at stake.
The symbology printed on the game board is in direct relation to the symboligy printed on smart charts.

In Dice's Zoo players compete to be the first to play out all twelve of their dice. On each side of each die is one kind of animal, some small and some large. When you play dice, you need to either play a bigger animal than the player before you or you can play the same animal but in a higher number. Whenever you play an animal, you may use that animal's special ability, for example, to hinder your opponent or to help you get rid of your dice faster.

item.description: A memory variant. 64 cards (32 pairs) are placed randomly on the table, face-down. Players take turns flipping over one tile and leaving it open. When a pair shows, all players try to put their hands on the two tiles. Whoever is first on any of the tiles gets it. The player with most tiles at the end of the game is the winner.

16 double-sided tiles with animal pictures are placed in a 4x4 grid.There is a stack of 15 cards with the same animals, and each player draws one of these. This shows his/her secret goal. 
Players now take turns flipping tiles. When an animal is showing on five tiles, the player(s) who have this animal as their goal shout "BIM BAMM". The first player to do that gets the card. The winner is the first player who has three cards.

In Sky Tango, you trace the cycles of the moon and the sun by creating series of cards that illustrate the passing of time. Eclipses can appear and ruin your paths, but don't let them discourage you for the sun and moon will always reappear. Will your solar and lunar cycles lead you to victory?

In game terms, the deck of cards consists of numbered sun and moon cards (some of which feature animals) as well as eclipse cards. Players place the cards in stacks in ascending order, either in front of themselves or in front of others. When a stack is five cards high, it can be removed and scored for points. Stacks can be interrupted by eclipse cards, which in turn can be covered by the appropriate sun or moon cards. Playing a card with an animal allows a player to play again, which is sometimes advantageous, but sometimes not. The player who removes the most cards from play wins!

link.value: Z-Man / Filosofia deluxe card game series

item.description: Som' Beans is a fun, fast card game for 2 to 4 players with a simple object: End the game with the most beans. What is involved in the game are a bag with 100 beans and a deck of 54 cards. Each player is dealt 6 cards and one player grabs out a handful of beans from the bag. From there players take beans from the pile, put them back, or take from other players. Once the last bean is taken by exact count, a player pulls out some more beans and the next round begins. When the bag is empty and the last bean is taken, count up. The most beans wins. Games take approximately 15 minutes.

Fantail Line presents "Fantail Basketball"
 Fantail Basketball is a board game agile and very fun where two teams try to put the ball into the hole by means of single, double or triple throws, and thus achieve higher score than your opponent.
 Smart Cards printed on both sides, (6) per team, are designed so that the rules and tactics of basketball can be developed on the game board.
 The symbols printed on the game board is directly related to the symbols printed on smart charts.
 A 10-sided roll dice cast by the team that has possession of the ball determines the way forward on the smart chart in use.
 In the smart chart of start o restart the game has some decisions that the team in possession of the ball to take.
 In other smart charts are designed situations related to the game of basketball itself, such as: passes between players, faults, recovery and loss of the ball, rebounds, throws and conversions.

Fantail Football is a board game designed under the Fantail Game. 
Fantail Football is a board game very agile and very entertaining where two teams try to score a goal and another and another and thus win the match.
 Smart Charts printed on both sides, (4) per team, are designed so that the rules and characteristics Football can be developed on the game board.
 The symbology printed on the game board is directly related to the symbolism printed on smart charts.
 A 12-sided roll dice cast for the team that has possession of the ball determines the way forward on the smart chart in use.
 In the smart charts are designed situations related with Football, such as: passes between players, fouls, off-sides, recovery and lost of the ball, free kicks, corners, centers to the goalposts and the desired goal.

Quantum Expanse uses ship models and counters on a grid-less flat playing surface. Typical games take between 1 to 2 hours to play. The player’s choose the size, conditions, and objectives of each battle.

The game is divided into rounds. In each round the players take turns moving their counters and ships, scanning to uncover stealth counters, or firing at opponents. At the end of the round players apply damage, make morale checks, use damage control to make repairs, and check to see if the game’s victory conditions have been met. The game ends when one player achieves their victory condition or when the flag ship is eliminated.

Simple, two-phase science-fiction game for 2-4 players, loosely based on Die Götter aus dem All comic series.

The first phase is a race to planet Orionus. Every player (up to two on each of the "rocket" and "ufo" sides) starts with six starships, and rolls a die to move, although one can choose which of the ships to move during their turn. Either shorter and harder or longer and easier route can be chosen. The ships can be destroyed by comets, monsters, or just crash during landing on the planet.

Only the ships that survived the race can take part in the second phase, played on a separate board that illustrates the surface of Orionus. This phase is more tactical, played "rockets" vs. "ufos", and the goal is to take over opponents' starting docs. It is possible to destroy enemy's ships by "landing" on them. The winner of the game is the person that will lock the most ships in opponents' starting docs.

name.value: Carole et ses drôles de recettes

item.description:
Carole – the game that includes a spatula! A player in the role of Carole the cow wants to make funny recipes, but she's missing eggs, carrots, hazelnuts, and chocolate. She takes the wooden spatula, picks up a recipe card, then taps on the table with the spatula to tell her friends the number of syllables in the needed ingredient.

The other players listen carefully while watching the cards of ingredients and try to find one that corresponds to the information they hear.

The first player to collect five winning recipe cards wins the game.

Objective: be the first to pass the finish line (100)
- moving by turns -
simple 'Roll and Move' game
if you land on an marked area follow instructions printed on cover inside
remarks:
published early 50's

Objective: be the first ending on space 43
- moving by turns -
simple 'Roll & Move' game - roll the die, move & follow instructions printed on cover inside

remarks:
belongs to series: "Scholz' künstlerische Spiele";
game should be published early 1920's
numbering (on box and rules) differs: 652 vs 472
meeples: pewter figures

This is a card games based on Mexican Politics for 3 or 4 players, the object of the game is to become the Mexican President.

The Game is played during 8 rounds, which represent the 8 week of campaigning.

In each round the players do one action and then draw one card. The actions that the players can do are, play or add a card to a support group, compete for a support group, play a scandal or pass.

The support groups that the players play will provide votes at the time of the election, these groups will advance the players in the polls which also provides votes at the elections, but beware life as a candidate is not easy, others players will throw scandals that may be your downfall as they will rest points in the polls and could make you lose.

This if the first game published by Creative Entertainment and Mexico based company which runs Gaming and Comic Book Conventions.

A two-player game of conspiracy among Masonic lodges in Enlightenment Germany. The Illuminati and the Rosicrucians are trying to extend their control over two principalities. Each player controls a Secret Master in one of the two countries, and they compete to see who can most effectively align the local initiates and their prince with the secret faction they support. (Freimaurerei is German for "Freemasonry." Pronounce it "FRY-mau-reh-rye")

The game requires nine stashes of Looney Pyramids, a deck of playing cards, dice, and an opaque bag. The Secret Master is a large opaque pyramid (black for Illuminati or white for Rosicrucian), who may be accurately representing his allegiance, or may have the opposite alignment concealed within. Blue pyramids represent Freemasons, who are further initiated into higher degrees by having smaller pyramids stacked on top of them. Small black and white pyramids are nested inside high-degree Masons to show their allegiance to the Rosicrucians or the Illuminati. Yellow and/or orange pyramids are used as money.

During the course of play, number cards are placed on the table to represent Masonic lodges, while face cards represent the rulers of the countries. Black suits are Illuminati-allied, and red ones belong to the Rosicrucians. Intrigue actions may change the alignment of rulers, make Mason pieces defect, inspire rulers to suppress lodges, etc.

A certain level of development is needed in order to call a stop to the game. At that point, true alignments are revealed and victory points are totaled. The apparent winner may actually be defeated. Bluffing and subterfuge are key to this game.

User Summary: Prototype 15mm fantasy rules based on the Brother Against Brother and Ge Koku Jo system.

Subtitle: Fantasy Miniatures Rules System

From the introduction: 
Battlecry: Age of Ravens (AOR) is a set of 15mm Fantasy Miniatures rules. Designed to cover large-scale battles, AOR is fast and flexible. Players control many strategic decisions, but some random elements such as turn sequence, movement and morale undercut this control in battle. The careful general will take these risks into account.

Age of Ravens is set in the world of Lowell. Here, after the fall of a great evil known as the Thonak, peoples and cultures struggle to reclaim what was lost. The races and history reflect this setting, but AOR can easily be adapted to a variety of other worlds.

Battle for Halo! After nearly three decades of war, the battle for humanity’s survival has come to Halo – an ancient and powerful ringworld built by the forerunners. As the UNSC, wage war against the implacable Covenant and a vicious parasite know as the Flood. If you select the Covenant, your mission is clear - eradicate all humans and activate Halo to initiate the Great Journey. As the Flood, you will infest the battlefield, mercilessly destroying all that stands in your way. The choice is yours but the goal is the same - win at all costs!

Game comes complete with: Over 290 custom game pieces:

3 all-new maps never before included in a table-top Risk edition, including a 60” Halo Ring Map for 3-5 players, and two 2-player maps including Anvil and Hammer that can be combined to create the Forge map for an additional 3-5 player game
Mobile Teleporters
UNSC Fire Bases, Marines, Scorpion Tanks and Spartans
Covenant Command Centers, Grunts, Wraith and Arbiters
Flood ProtoGraveminds, Infection Forms, Carrier Forms and Juggernaut Colonies
UNSC, Covenant & Flood Faction Cards
5 dice
4 new ways to play!

item.description:
In Myrmes, originally shown under the name ANTerpryse, players control ant colonies and use their ants to explore the land (leaving pheromones in their wake); harvest "crops" like stone, earth and aphids; fight with other ants; complete requests from the Queen; birth new ants; and otherwise dominate their tiny patch of dirt, all in a quest to score points and prove that they belong at the top of the heap, er, anthill. After three seasons of scrabbling and foraging, each ant colony faces a harsh winter that will test its colonial strength.

In game terms, each player has an individual game board to track what's going on inside his colony – that is, whether the nurses are tending to larvae or doing other things, where the larvae are in their growth process, what resources the colony has, which actions are available to workers when they leave the colony, and so on. The shared game board shows the landscape outside the exit tunnel that all colonies share; after exiting this tunnel, workers ants can move over the terrain to place pheromones (which gives them access to resource cubes), clean up empty pheromones (to make space), hunt prey (by discarding soldiers) or place special tiles (but only if they've developed the ant colony).

The game lasts three years, and at the start of each year three season dice are rolled to determine the event for each season: extra larvae or soldiers, more VPs for actions, and so on. Within each season, players can spend larvae to adjust the event for themselves on their personal player board. (Put the kids to work!) After adjusting the event, player allocate nurses to birth larvae, worker or soldier ants or to use them for other actions. The worker ants then do their thing, working within the colony itself (although only one colony level is open initially) or traveling to the outside world to hunt prey (ladybugs, termites, spiders), lay down pheromones (which later lets them claim resources on these spaces), place special tiles (like an aphid farm or sub-colony), or clear out pheromones left by ants from any colony. After harvesting, nurses who didn't tend to births then take additional actions, such as opening a new tunnel that only your colony can use, clearing a new level within your colony, or meeting one of the six objectives (capture a certain number of prey, build special tiles, and so on) laid out at the start of the game.

After three seasons, players must pay food to get their colony through winter, losing points if they can't. Whoever has the most points after three years wins. All hail our new ant overlords!

item.description:
Boom & Zoom by designer Ty Bomba is a two-player strategy game about the “wars of the future” where Laser Tower vehicles conduct fire and movement across the battlefield. This game abstracts warfare in much the same way as Checkers or Chess, with similarly deep gameplay. Quick to learn, but difficult to master, can you outmaneuver your opponent and claim the victory for your side?

Choose one of two factions - Consolidated Tech or Pan Asian - and prepare for abstract, virtual reality warfare. As a tower-jockey, you take control of several laser towers and strategize your way to make it across the board to win!

In this BattlessonTM game, players receive stackable pieces (the "Towers"), set up on a Chess-like board. With a variety of different missions to choose from, command and control your towers as they Zoom (move) and Boom (fire at other Towers) their way to the other side of the board to score. With treacherous terrain, Tower tactics, and more to add onto your game, can you push your way past every obstacle? Get onto the field with Boom & Zoom!

Game Data:

Complexity: 2 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 2 on a 9 scale
Scale: Each player takes control of the red or blue side, each with stackable laser tower forces, and attempts to reach the other side with them.

item.description:
In Die, Robot, Die! players command an army of 8 robots, represented by dice. The game is played on a grid, with each player having a "base" on their side of the grid. The object of the game is to either destroy the opponent's base, destroy the opponent's entire army, or make it so that none of the opponent's army can move on their turn.

On a player's turn, first a player may sabotage the opponent's base (if they have a die alone in the opponent's base), which reduces the health of the base. If the players destroys the base in this manner, they win.

A player must then move one of their armies according to the pips shown on the dice. If the player has no legal move, he loses.

Lastly, a player may attack one of the opponent's dice, with the attacker gaining pips, and the defender losing pips according to the pips currently showing on the dice. If a die is reduced to 0 or less pips in the battle, that army is eliminated from the game. If a die ends up getting too many pips, that army is "overloaded" and dies as well!

Die, Robot Die! is contained in the centerfold of Spielbox Magazine, Issue #3 of 2012. You will need to supply your own dice and tokens to play.

A party game where guests are each given a card with 18 pictures on it. The pictures are visual cryptic clues to something found in a garden. For example, picture number 10 is a pair of lips and the answer is Tulips (Two Lips - geddit?). There are 18 such clues to solve and the first to hand in a completely correct card, wins.

This is one of the publisher's range entitled Can You Solve?

Party game. Each participating guest gets a card with 18 cryptic clues to words. First to get them all right, wins. Or the one with the most answers when 'Time' is called, wins.

Part of the publisher's Can You Solve? party game range.

Baroj (barriers) is a breaktrough/race board game inspired on the Robert Abbot's masterpiece "Epaminondas", wich can be played on a square or a hexagonal grid. Pieces move 1 or 2 cells forward orthogonally and diagonally, (sideways and backwards moves are not allowed) and captures are made by jumping orthogonally over an adjacent friendly piece and falling on an adjacent enemy piece, in straight line. Captures can be made in any of 4 directions (so backwards and sideways captures are allowed, but not diagonally). The goal of the game is to place and keep 2 of your pieces on your enemy´s first row.

Best board sizes recommended are 7x8 or 8x8.

The game can be played on a hexagonal grid with 5 or 6 cells per side. Here, pieces can move even sideways, but not backward. The moved piece must advance forward at least one cell at the end of the turn. Captures are made in straight line in any of 6 directions.

Up to four players each have a wooden board with 10 holes for pegs. They blindly draw colored pegs out of the can which is also used to store the game. If the peg is their color, them they get to score it, otherwise the peg is discarded and it is the next players turn. Two specially colored pegs. A silver peg forces a player to remove one of his pegs and return it to the can. A gold peg gives the player three more draws in the same turn.

The game was packaged in a round can about 3.5 inches in diameter and 4.75 inches tall.

Edgewise is a speed matching tile game where you race to play your 12 player chips first by matching the edges to the starter chip of each round or any player chips already played. There are twelve rounds that change with each starter chip. A point is scored for each chip played along with bonus points. The most points at the end of all the rounds wins the game. The game can be customized to however many rounds you want to play. If your time is limited, you can play 2-3 different rounds in under 20 minutes. You can also have multiple games going at the same time since Edgewise has 12 starter chips that determine each round.

Contents: 84 hexagon-shaped game pieces
Game Pieces: 72 Player Tiles (12-Black, 12-Turquoise, 12-Pink, 12-Green, 12-Orange, 12-Purple), 12 Starter Tiles (1-"Basic" round, 1-"Follow the Leader" round, 1-"Teams" round, 1-"Longest Chain" round, 1-"No Reds" round, 1-"Opposites Attract" round, 1-"Stack 'Em" round, 1-"Capture" round, 1-"Dead End" round, 1-"Freeze Tag" round, 1-"Rotate" round, 1-"Share the Love" round)

A simple roll and move game. Players start in Southampton and then follow the track around the British Isles, ending up back at Southampton. Certain spaces give help or hindrance along the way. First to get back there, wins.

name.value: Tactical Commander: World War II Skirmish Rules

item.description:
These wargame rules are for World War II 1/76th scale battles and skirmishes. They have been formulated over half a dozen years and countless battlefields. They provide for almost every aspect of late World War II battles, with sections on air and naval support, paratroop, glider and beach landings, with a good blend of detail, realism, and playability.

64 pages

This 92 page handbook provides the most comprehensive coverage of all armoured vehicles, artillery, helicoptes and missiles which are in service or have been in service since the 1950s. The data is laid out for Tabeltop Games Challenger II rules and WRG's Armoured Warfare 1950 to 1985, but is also detailed enough to be of interest to other armoured vehicle enthusiasts.

name.value: Unit Organizations of World War II

item.description:
The purpose of this book is to present a Table of Organization & Equipment (TO&E) for several basic ground combat units found in most armies that directly participated in World War II

Each TO&E Chart identifies division to platoon sized units that can be easily duplicated in any scale.

Each of the units can be duplicated on a 1-on-1 ratio where an actual 42 man platoon is represented by 42 scale men with appropriate equipment and weapons

Objective: Be the first turning back to your starting point & collecting all 3 wooden chips, placed at 3 different corners.

- Place your meeple onto appropriate (coloured) corner of the board & 3 of your chips into all other corners.
 - Roll the die by turns: move according the number into direction free of choice; ending on an arrow move into that direction next turn; ending on an image you are going to be teleported to the appropriate second image; passing a corner collect your wooden chip.

remarks:
very cute wooden meeples - produced in the Erz Mountains; one of the reasons why this game is rather difficult to get

There can be only one. One court jeweler, that is. And of course this can only be you, if nothing fishy's going on. 
But isn't it always? It is right here and right now in the kingdom of Gemonaria. Here the best jeweler has to prove herself / himself by cleverly obtaining gold and jewels from the gemstone market and creating more beautiful jewelry than her / his opponents in a contest.
Only this way can she / he impress her / his king / queen (delete as applicable) and become court jeweler.

Jewel Duel is a largely abstract family level strategy game by Thomas Staudt for 1 - 4 players that compete for resources (wooden cubes) using a novel chip mechanic in order to create jewelry (buy cards) and accumulate the most victory points.

This game is available as a free print & play download.

item.description:
This two player print and play game is actually inspired from a variant of Fire from the Sky. This game depicts the battle between two small armies of 9 soldiers each in a board of 25 grids(5 rows and 5 columns.) Three dice are also used. Each player takes the control of an army.

All the soldier tokens are placed in the board, one token per square. The soldiers are imagined to have both melee weapons(sword or mace) and ranged weapons. The players can throw up to three dice per turn to determine an action to be taken on the war field (board). The number of dice thrown are determined by the number of soldiers he has left on the field. Nine to seven soldiers means he can throw three dice. Six to four means he can throw 2 dice and three to one soldiers means he can throw just one die.

Out of the dice he can choose any one as a row number and the other as column number. (means more the number of soldiers he has more choices at his disposal). If the grid on the field selected using this row and column has an enemy soldier, the enemy soldier is removed. If it has the player's own soldier, he can move one square and can capture an enemy soldier if there's one in that square.

If the user threw six, he can use it to destroy an entire row(chose a six and a row number ), or an entire column (chose a six and column number) or a combination of both (when he chose a double six for row and column), killing enemy soldiers and maybe his own soldiers as collateral damage.

Objective: be the first to pass finish line (field 90)
simple 'Roll and Move' game - use only one die between 1-14 and above 72, otherwise 2 dice
remarks:
very cute drawings
very nice coloured pewter figures
should had been published between 1910-15

Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name.value: Disney Club Penguin Card Game Fast Flippers!

item.description:
One of Club Penguin's first card games to play with your friends in real life. In this game you use Disney's Club Penguin characters and locations to find matches.

6 island cards are placed on the play surface face up and one see through penguin card is placed face up on each island. Each player takes a turn to flip a character card (which shows a penguin on an island) from their draw pile and put it on a common pile. All players then try to find matches with the penguins on the island cards. The first person to spot the match calls it out and collects the common pile (and add the cards to the bottom of their draw pile) and the island/see through penguin cards are removed from play.

Description from the box: "Are your flippers fast enough to catch the most Penguins! Lay down the unique see-thru Penguin character cards on the Background Island cards, then use your "fast flippers" to pick-up as many Club Penguin cards as possible!"

A Fox and Geese type game played on an irregular network of positions. The one red scout is trying to reach the bottom of the board and get back home. The six blue scouts are trying to block him so that he cannot move.

Omen is a game of strategy, luck, and magic!

Harness the power of the elements to cast spells that enhance your abilities and hinder your opponents in a race around the kingdom.

Become the most powerful sorcerer by creating elemental Gems, but be careful; draw an Omen card and your luck will flip on its head!

HOW TO PLAY: 
In Omen, players embody 1 of 4 elements and strive to become the most powerful sorcerer. Each turn, players roll the dice and move across the board. If players land on an element space, they collect the corresponding Elemental card and place a Totem, which gives them ownership of that space. The more Totems a player has in play, the more chance they have of collecting Elemental Cards from opponents who land on their spaces, and the more cards they get passing their Castle (home base). These Elemental cards are in turn used to cast devious spells on opponents, or help the player in different ways. Elemental cards are also used to create Gems. The first player to collect 7 of each Elemental card they don't represent and use those to create 3 Gems is the winner.

"Omen is the brainchild of Benjamin Conner, an avid board-gamer who works in the Visual Effects Industry. Having never made a board game before, Benjamin sought out copies of all the most popular games and dissected each one to find out what made it tick, and more importantly what made it fun. Omen is the fantastical game that resulted out of those years of research. Simple and elegant yet full of strategy, Omen is sure to please the whole family and keep you yearning for more."

Scenarios for WWII 1/300th or 1/200th scale wargames. It can also operate with the Challenger II rules system (1988).

Includes both historical and fictional battles.

All scenarios are laid out in common format:
1. Background
2. Game Size
3. Conditions
4. Force Lists
5. Reinforcements
6. Notes

Also, each scenario has a map included

Probsub is a set of rules which simulates modern combat betwen nuclear submarines, and also includes anti-submarine aircraft and helicopters. All aspects of anti-submarine warfare are covered except the use of surface vessels.

This book is a supplement to Corps Commander OMG and that book is required to be used in conjuction with this one.

Extensive rules are included for all airborne operations and in an abstract way amphibious assaults. The army lists include all of the remainder of NATO countries, even Luxembourg! Together with WARPAC air naval assault units. Operations on NATOs Norther and Southern Flanks can now be simulated including overseas reinforcements and special forces.

name.value: The Ebb and Flow of Battle: Module 3 – The Peninsular Campaign

item.description:
Grand tactical warfare rules focusing on 1809-1811 featuring the defense of Portugal and the securing of a base for operation with the capture of the fortress of Cuidad Rodrigo and Badajoz.

Dice are not used with these rules

Tricorne is a set of rules for warfare in the 18th century. They cover the period of transition from the pike and shot armed regiments to the mass armies of the Revolutionary Wars.

Ground Scale:
20/25mm miniatures - 1 inch = 10 yards
15/18mm miniatures - 1 cm = 10 yards

Bonaparte is a set of wargame rules which recreate warfare in the era between the French Revolution and Napoleon's final defeat at Waterloo

Ground Scale:
20/25mm - 1" = 10 yards
10/12/15mm - 1cm = 10 yards
6mm - 1cm = 20 yards

Figure Scale
1 figure = 50 real men
1 gun model = up to 6 pieces

name.value: Deal or no Deal: Elektronische Versie

item.description:
Analogous to the TV program you can now play with family and friends about the big money. 
Everyone chooses one of the suitcases from the electronic board and each round a certain number of cases opened, then the bank makes an offer based on the remaining sum, the player can accept or reject, he refuses to be in the next round, open suitcase. Who will score the higher amount, whether by accepting the bank offer or the amount in the last remaining case is the winner.

link.value: TV Series: Deal or No Deal

item.description:
Objective: be the first covering all 10 numbers of your playing segment

acting by turns -
each player gets 10 (coloured) chips
player with red starts turning the spinner
 - if a number within his own (coloured) segment is shown by the arrow => cover that number with a chip
 - if a number within another coloured segment is shown by the arrow => correspondent player puts a chip on this number
 - if an already covered number is shown by the arrow => correspondent player puts a chip on the following number (+1)
 - if a 'zero' is shown => each player has to remove 1 chip

This game simulates players trying to hit a target at the far end of a playing field using stones or similar projectiles. The target is either suspended in the air or on the ground, which will be agreed upon by the players. A graph paper or grid paper (10x10 or 20x20) represents the playing field. The movement of the projectiles per turn is determined by a standard die roll. Each player has four projectiles to throw. If the projectile hits the target or misses it, it is discarded from the game.

Each move starts with a dice roll. The player moves his projectile according to the dice roll. For each dice roll, the user can choose to move a projectile which is already airborne or introduce a new projectile into the playing field. For the initial moves the projectile has to travel towards the sky (top of the graph paper) in a diagonal manner (towards top right). After the projectile is airborne, the player can choose whether the projectile has to fall down in this turn. If he chooses so, then the projectile will have to move horizontally for this turn and the next turn onwards the projectile moves towards bottom right(ground) diagonally. The projectile always move to the right and cannot go back. (Should obey laws of gravity and projectile motion). The target is always placed at the second half of the paper, towards the right edge.

If the projectile hits the target the player is awarded 5 points. If the projectile hits another players projectile (lands in the same square) in the second half (right half) of the graph sheet, then 1 point is awarded and the opponent projectile is removed. The player can hit another player's projectile only in the second half of the field.Game continues till all projectiles are removed from the graph paper. The player with most points wins.

In Lady Alice – a game of intrigue, flair, bluffing, and mischief – the players are the Baker Street Kids, children under the tutelage of Sherlock Holmes who must deduce the culprit behind the kidnapping of Henry Morton Stanley as well as the time and place the kidnapping occurred and which object was stolen at the same time.

Holmes gives each player the solution to one of these categories at the start of the game, and players must keep such information secret. On a turn, the active player voices his suspicions in the form of a sentence – "I suspect ....... of having been seen at ....... at around ....... hundred in possession of ......." – filling in the blanks with one of the eight possibilities in each category. All players then secretly note whether or not they hold the evidence card for one of the four things named by placing a verdict card inside a folder. The active player shuffles these folders to disguise who answered in which ways, then reveals them. If all four items guessed were false, then you cover those four guesses on the game board with Holmes' business cards; otherwise players mentally note how many of the items were correct and try to decipher which ones those might be.

Players then participate in a deduction round in which each player can:


 Place a deduction token on a clue.
 Say "I pass".
 Attempt an accusation.


If all players pass successively, the round ends and the next player in clockwise order then voices a suspicion. Otherwise a player can pass, then place a deduction token or attempt an accusation later in the same round.

Each player has nine deduction tokens in his color, three each of 0, 1 and 2. To place a token, you place it face-down on the clue of your choice to the right of any tokens already present; if any of those tokens are face-down, you reveal those tokens. At most four tokens can be placed on a clue.

To attempt an accusation, you say, "I accuse (suspect) of having been been seen at (place) at around (time) in possession of (object)", then all players submit their verdict cards the same way they normally do. If all of them are positive, you've solved the case – but not necessarily won the game. All tokens on incorrect clues and all tokens belonging to players who made a false accusation are removed, then players tally the numbers on their tokens, scoring bonus points if they have a token on each piece of evidence, or if they made a correct suspicion or accusation. The player with the most points wins.

With three or five players, you decrease (increase) the number of evidence cards handed out at the start of the game and the number of tokens that can be placed on a clue.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
The game consists of thirty-two cards, representing eight cats and twenty-four mice and the cards are lay out on the table in 8x4 grid face-down.

In his turn, the active player may turn any card face-up.
If it's a mouse he may continue his turn turning another card or decide to stop and take all visible mice in front of him. 
If it's a cat, his turn is over and he must turn all cards face-down again.

When all mice were found, the player who has the most mice wins the game.

From Noris edition:

Katz und Maus - Wer findet die meisten Mäuse
translated: Cat and mouse - who finds the most mice

From the box back that also contains the games rules:

The game consits of 32 cards depicting cats and mice. 24 cards are with mice, 8 cards with cats. They are laid out face down in a 4 by 8 grid after a good shuffle. A player turns over cards on his turn. When the revealed card is a mouse its good and he can continue turning over cards. He can secure his winnings and keep the mice or continue. When a cat is revealed the players turn is immediately over, the face up cards are turned face down again, the next players turn begins. Whoever has the most mice when all mice are revealed is the winner.

A simple push your luck game for children.

Snow on the ground? No problem you can still play golf using a real score card with the game Rough Water. Swings are dealt from a card deck and you score for the hole is recorded just like on a real golf course.

Crossword board game for two! 
Game box contains a blank crossword grid, two packets of letters one for each player, some black squares and two books of identical definitions.

In his turn player can form one word from the book placing the missing letters to the crossword board.

At the end of the game, the winner is the one with the most letters in its color on the game board.

Build a ship and race around antarctic answering the Trivia questions about sailing.
Rolling different numbers and answering questions correctly players first earns ship parts and then roll and move around antarctic.

Mimic (Memory Interfaced Micro Integrated Computer) is an electronic game similar to Simon. Colored LEDs light up in an ever increasing pattern, and the object is to "mimic" what has been shown each turn (and heard with beeps for each of the four colored buttons).
There are 3 play modes (1, 2, 3 -- not sure what these do) and 4 levels of difficulty (novice, amateur, junior, and pro) that can be set with two switches.

name.value: Mickey Mouse Electric Treasure Hunt Game

item.description:
The game is made by Tudor, the company who brought you the vibrating Electric Football game. Teamed up with Disney, this much simpler (and as a result, more fun for kids) game uses that same clever technology. Happily, all you have to do to play is put your ship in one of the tracks and let it go. You can adjust the knob on the board to control the speed (amount of vibration), but you don’t have to fiddle with anything else to play! Just flip the switch and you’re off to search for treasure!

Players choose from one of 4 - '1.5" long' ships made of tin and plastic, which are piloted by either Mickey, Donald, Goofy or Pluto. Each character has a differently colored background on their game piece. There are four Ports to choose from as a starting point for each player.

The goal is to sail for the Treasure Chests at the top, worth from $200 to $500! Many sailors will be side tracked along the way into one of the many Coves where lesser treasure of $100 can still be found. But watch out! Captain Hook is on the prowl as his ship starts out from Pirate’s Cove from the top of the board and if you are intercepted by his ship, you’re sunk!

Some of the lesser treasure coves along the routes include names like Smugger's Cove, Doubloon Cove, Neverland Cove, Skeleton Cove, Shark Cove and several others. The Treasure Chests at the top include Captain Kidd's Treasure, Captain Morgan's Treasure, Captain Hook's Treasure and Long John Silver's Treasure.

DESCRIPTION OF HOW TO PLAY PROVIDED BY Jason Monroe
(belial1134) after a short visit to the Unidentified Games Area

Seven honorable and brave samurai, aided by a handful of frightened villagers, are the only defenders of the village. Will you help these villagers to fend off bandits, or will you command the thieves to steal all the rice you can and punish the insolent peasants?

Seven Swords is a game for two players in which one player controls seven samurai and the villagers to try to repel the attack of the evil villains while the other player controls the bandits who try to steal all the rice they can and destroy the village. The game lasts 18 turns, after which the player with the most victory points (VPs) wins. The samurai player begins the game with the VPs in the villagers' houses and rice stores, and the bandit player must attack peasant houses and steal rice to acquire these VPs. The bandit player can also earn extra points if he eliminates the samurai in combat.

Each turns consists of two phases. The bandit, who plays first, has seven cards in hand that symbolize the seven sectors of the village. He discards a card to give himself a number of actions that turn, and he might receive additional actions from the samurai player. With these actions, the bandit can play different bandit troops – including infantry, archers and cavalry – with which he can then move around the village and attack the samurai, villagers and rice storage. The samurai player then chooses between five chips – combat, movement, leadership and two special action chips – to see how many actions that he has that turn. A samurai can perform three types of actions – attack, move, and use the villagers to attack bandits – but only one time for each samurai until one of the special chips has removed the counters of such action. The more actions that the samurai player performs, the more actions the bandit has.

After a certain number of turns, the bandit player discards one of his action cards, then eliminates any samurai who is in the field of the discarded card. Other details in the game include bows that help players attack from a distance and fences that keep the bandits from just walking into the village. In addition to having a double-sided game board with different village layouts, the samurai player establishes the placement of villagers, fences, nows and rice storage at the start of each game, allowing for wide variability in gameplay.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
The people call out for Justice. We’ll give them Justice. They call out for Liberty and we’ll give them that too. We’ll give them everything that they call out for, exactly as we’ve designed. And in our magnanimity we will turn the ear of the King in our favor. That is when things really start to change. For once you’ve had the King’s ear, his eyes are sure to move too. Sooner or later, you may find that you’ve gotten hold of his whole head.

Our time is coming and if we have to swallow our pride and dance a dance for King and people while biding our time, then so be it. We have a vision for this land, and by the power invested in us, we will make it so.


Of Pride & Policy is a game of political maneuvering for 3-5 players. There are 4 sets of opposing political issues in the game each one with a color and symbol:

Expansionism Vs. Isolationism
Conservatism Vs. Liberalism
Industry Vs. Agriculture
Liberty Vs. Justice

The kingdom is divided into 5 regions: Galicia, Castilla, Madrid, Portugal and Andalucia. Each region is divided into 5 or 7 territories. Each territory will have particular concern in one of the eight political issues.

Each player represents a Noble family. At the start of the game players will have no particular stance on any of the issues; however, this will soon change. Players will influence both territories and legislation in order to advance in the Court of the King. All the while, the political state of the kingdom will change.

In Western in my Pocket, players take on the role of a heroic Sheriff in the old west. Take out the hideout of the Notorious Jones Gang before they rob the noon train!

Western in my Pocket started as a spinoff to Zombie in my Pocket.

Western in my Pocket is a Solitaire tile-laying adventure game set in the Old West. Players lay tiles beginning at the Sheriff's Office, and must find dynamite at the Survey Camp and get to the mine and blow it up before noon. While you're doing this, there are bandits around that will try and stop you. Western in my Pocket features a modular board, so no 2 games are ever the same.

There are also scenarios planned to expand upon the base game, and offer the player more fun in the Old West.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
This is a two player abstract strategy game played on a chessboard (simulates a brawl between two mobs in an enclosed area). This is played with eight pawns per side. Pawns start from the opposite extreme ranks. White moves first. Movements are as per pawn movement in chess. But opponent's pawns are not captured when they come in diagonally to each other. Instead they are pushed one square backward orthogonally. If there is no space to move orthogonally (square occupied by another pawn or there is no space in the board) then the attacked pawn is captured. One point is awarded per captured pawn and for each pawn which reach the opposite ranks. Game ends when no more pawns can be moved for either side. Player with most points wins.

Game rules will be uploaded soon.

Childrens game where the players race to complete a jigsaw first.

Each player chooses a different colour and is given the eight pieces that will make up a picture of Pippi Langstrumpf. In your turn, you roll the special die. The die has freckles instead of numbers except for the face that shows the monkey Herr Nilsson. If the monkey is rolled, that player can start to assemble his jigsaw and he may continue to try until another player rolls the monkey and cries "Stop!". Then that player can start his jigsaw. It continues in this way until someone has completed the puzzle and that person is the winner.

BLITZ BOLIDE is a racing car game based on Formula 1 race. 
THE PURPOSE OF BLITZ BOLIDE IS TO PLAY WITH 1/64 MINIATURE AND HAVE GREAT FUN IN DOING THAT. At this scale, a car has 7,5 cm or 3 inches length.
Blitz Bolide is played on tracks which are made of spaces. The average length of a lap is between 40 spaces (fast tracks) and 60 spaces (long tracks).

HOW TO PLAY : a car has four levels of gear : low, intermediate, high, and extreme.
Each turn, his driver can increase or decrease this gear by 1 level.
After that, he rolls 2 dice : according to the results of the dice, and according to the gear, the car is moved by a certain number of spaces. 
Move bonuses (in terms of spaces) are given by tyres, fuel gauge, suspension, etc...
Once moved, a car can engage another car in order to gain its position.

There are two important difficulties in the game :
a) How to manage the Damage Points (DP) ? 
Each car begins the race with 8 DPs. DPs are lost during brutal brakings, during engagement, when the car is going out of track, at extreme gear, etc...
A car is eliminated if it goes under 0 DP.
The higher the speed, the faster you lose DPs. But you cannot win if your speed is too low...Here Pit Stop strategy is very important for purpose of managing DPs.
b) How to take the corners ?
Each corner has an optimal gear. If its gear exceeds the optimal gear while taking a corner, a car can goes out of track (losing speed and possibly DPs). 
However, a driver has 3 choices when his car is about to take a bend : short, medium, or long trajectory. With a short trajectory, you go faster, but it's risky. With a long trajectory, you take the corner more easily, but you become an easy target if engaged by opponents...
Here, tyre strategy, set-up (aero grip, suspension, etc..), are very important things for purpose of taking a corner.

Basic rules cover : hard or soft tyres, fuel gauge, pit stop, optimal gear in bend, fast bend, etc...
Advanced rules cover :advanced set-up (pit stop efficiency, bolide's toughness, etc...) defective gearbox, rain tyres, meteo.
Expert rules cover : aero grip, suspension, oversteering, understeering, engine power, qualification lap, Events card.

For the moment, there are 8 tracks : Monaco, Canada, Belgium, Japan, Italy, Catalunya, Singapore, China.

Statistical golf replay game. Players are rated in various skills based on their performances in competitions like the Ryder Cup. Dice are used to give results based on the skill in question at that time. It would be quite easy to use the system to rate players up to date.

Bernhard Langer on the cover.

Statistical hockey game replaying the 1936 Olympic ice hockey competition. Fond memories for me as it is the replay of the most unexpected result in Olympic Ice Hockey. Britain, yes - Britain, won the gold medal. Unbridled joy in the whole country.

It is a dice based statistical simulation. All the teams that took part are rated in areas of ability based on their performances that year. You could replay the whole competition in one evening.

Self-published by the designer.

Statistical boxing replay game. Dice decide results of fights by comparing the dice throw to charts based on the real boxer's ability. Designed so that a lot of fights can be recreated in one evening.

Includes Charts and the designer's Boxer Rating System. Over 1600 champions and contenders rated, from the 1800's to the 1990's.

One-on-one fight game in a Shuggy Hall, in the world of Judge Dredd. A Shuggy Hall is a futuristic amusement arcade as described in the comic 2000 A.D. Players are various characters, all trying to be top dog in the fight.

Players choose actions - hit someoine very hard, throw a glass of beer at someone, that sort of thing. Dice decide how successful you were in your choice and, if successful, the affect it has on the recipient.

The game was included in Warlock magazine, issue 11.

A statistical game based on Rugby League. (For those that don't know, at the end of six tackles possession of the ball passes to the opposing side, which then has six tackles to try to advance up the field).

In the designer's familiar style, teams are rated based on their performances in recent years. Various charts are used as dice rolls are compared to the action in that turn.

The original Lambourne Games edition was published in 1988. The later version licensed to Owzat Games features team cards for the 1999 English domestic competition.

An expansion based on the 2003 Australian National Rugby League competition is also available.

link.value: Sixth Tackle: 2003 Australian NRL Season Cards

item.description:
Statistical soccer game from the master of such quick replay games. Based on statistics culled from both the indoor and outdoor soccer leagues in America.

Each team is rated for each year and a simple dice roll decides the result. This way you could play a season in one evening, I think that was the aim of the designer.

Promotional game published on behalf of MFS Associates, a firm of insurance brokers.

54 cards illustrated with the strip, club crest and nickname of 18 professional rugby league clubs. There are three cards to a set. Very simple game of drawing cards and discarding, but laying down a set if you manage to collect one. When all the cards are used, the player with the most sets, wins.

From the expert designer of fast-play statistical sports games. This one features ice hockey teams and leagues. 20 years of statistics are used, from the early 90's back to the 70's. The intention is to let you play a whole season in an evening or, at the very least, all your favourite team's matches.

Dice determine outcomes after rolls are compared to the various charts provided.

name.value: Mafioso: The Underworld Strategy Card Game

item.description:
Mafioso is a game of cards and dice set in the seedy world of organized crime. In it two to five players must compete to build the most lucrative criminal empire while preventing their opponents from doing the same thing.
 Players are each dealt a hand of seven cards from which they play Wiseguy cards to form a Crew, and then in turn use their Wiseguy's "stats" (Honor, Greed, Power, and Influence) to play Front Company and Racket cards to build wealth. They may also use their "stats" to play War cards to attack opposing Crews, destroy opposing Crews' Empires, or steal their opponents' Rackets for themselves. Also, they may attack enemy Crews directly using Dice attacks, forcing wiser, wealthier Crews to defend themselves with strategic use of their own resources such as Wiseguy Modifiers and Retaliation cards. As the game progresses, Rat cards are added to the deck, a threat to every Crew on the table.

The goal of Mafioso is to be the Crew with the most valuable Empire on the table at the end of the game, for only the crew with the most lucrative Empire will be chosen by Big Sal to remain a part of the Gouldini Crime Family, and the rest will be "fed to the fishes".

This is a fishing trivia game with a wide variety of questions in two booklets... it isn't just about bass fishing.

Player move along the pathway as they answer questions in the following categories:

Fishin' Lore -- History & Tall Tales
Fishin' Gear -- Rods & Reels, Lures, Boats, etc.
Fishin' Holes -- Geography
Fishteristics -- Fish Characteristics
Fishpourri -- Everything Else

The first player to reach the finish line and answer the bonus question is declared the winner.

Includes a colorful board, two question booklets, tokens, die, and a storage insert.

The Chamberlain is searching the realm for a new "Craftmaster to the King" and sets a contest for all of the smiths and crafters in the land. The first one to forge four items from a list of the King's favorite weapons and trinkets will be honored as First Among Crafters and Smiths. But watch out, because the other crafters and smiths will try to outdo you at every opportunity. Are you ready to forge your destiny?

In King's Forge, players are craftsmen and craftswomen seeking to become the favorite of the King. A variety of dice represent the raw materials (metal, wood, gems, and enchantment) and those same dice can be used to gather new dice and purchase roll-modifiers, or saved and rolled in an attempt to meet the requirements to craft the items on the King's list. An early lead is not a sure path to victory and other players will out-maneuver and out-build you whenever possible. Careful dice management, advance planning, fierce competition, and nail-biting luck will carry you to winner's circle.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

link.value: King's Forge: Game of Ingenuity Exclusive Craft Card
King's Forge: Hi-Energy Specs Craft Cards
King's Forge: Ring of the Lords Kickstarter Exclusive Craft Card

item.description:
The goal of "Oldies Game" is for each player to move his or her tokens to the finish line as quickly as possible. The first player to do so, wins. The winner, thereby, proves that he or she is not "old", but is still "young".

By rolling dice, players move around the game board into different colour-coded areas. Each area provides various obstacles to overcome (as explained on the game board) and assignments to complete (as explained on cards drawn in play). These obstacles and assignments can involve both physical stamina and brain power. In some cases, players "duel" directly with their opponents in order to progress on the game board.
